pageProps.body:
Differential Equations

A differential equation involved an unknown function yyy and its derivatives. The unknown in a differential equation is not a number, but rather a function.

Some examples of differential equations include...

  • dydx+4y=cos⁡x\frac{dy}{dx}+4y=\cos{x}dxdy​+4y=cosx
  • d2ydx2+16y=0\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}+16y=0dx2d2y​+16y=0
  • y′(t)=0.1y(100−y)y'(t)=0.1y(100-y)y′(t)=0.1y(100−y)

xxx ant ttt are commonly used as the independent variables (ttt is generally used for time-dependent problems).

Goal

The purpose of solving a differential equation is to find the function yyy that satisfies the differential equation.

For example, if substituting y=cos⁡4xy=\cos{4x}y=cos4x and y′′=−16cos⁡4x=0y''=-16\cos{4x}=0y′′=−16cos4x=0 into the second equation above, we get...

−16cos⁡4x+16cos⁡4x=0,-16\cos{4x}+16\cos{4x}=0\text,−16cos4x+16cos4x=0,

with y=cos⁡4xy=\cos{4x}y=cos4x reflected on the righthand side of the +++ sign and y′′=−16cos⁡4xy''=-16\cos{4x}y′′=−16cos4x reflected on the lefthand side of the +++ sign. This implies that y=cos⁡4xy=\cos{4x}y=cos4x is a solution to the differential equation.

Terminology

The general first-order linear differential equation has the form

dydt+p(t)y=q(t),\frac{dy}{dt}+p(t)y=q(t)\text,dtdy​+p(t)y=q(t),

where ppp and qqq are given functions of ttt. This equation is linear because yyy and y′y'y′ appear to the first power and not in products or compositions involving yyy or y′y'y′.

Order

The order of a differential equation is the highest order that appears on a derivative in the equation.

Of the three examples, the first two are first order, and the third is second order.

Linear

A differential equation is linear if the unknown function yyy and its derivatives appear only to the first power and are not composed with other functions. A linear equation also cannot have products or quotients of yyy and its derivatives.

Of the examples, the first two are linear, and the third is nonlinear (because the right side contains y2y^2y2).

A linear differential equation cannot have terms such as y2y^2y2, yy′yy'yy′, or sin⁡y\sin{y}siny, where yyy is the unknown function.

General Solution

Differential equations can be solved through integration. You must "undo" the derivative y′(t)y'(t)y′(t) in order to find yyy.

The most general solution of a first-order differential equation involves one arbitrary constant, whereas a second-order differential equation requires two arbitrary constants. This carries onto equations of nnnth order, where they have nnn arbitrary constants.

Initial Conditions

A differential equation is often accompanied by initial conditions that specify the values of yyy and possibly y′y'y′ at the start of the problem.

In general, a differential equation of the nnnth order requires nnn initial conditions, which are used to determine the nnn arbitrary constants in the general solution.

A differential equation with the appropriate initial conditions is called an initial value problem. A first-order initial value problem generally has the form

y′(t)=F(t,y)Differential equationy(a)=b,Initial condition\begin{matrix} y'(t)=F(t,y)&\text{Differential equation}\\ y(a)=b\text,&\text{Initial condition} \end{matrix}y′(t)=F(t,y)y(a)=b,​Differential equationInitial condition​

where aaa and bbb are the initial values, and FFF is a given expression that involves ttt and/or yyy. A solution to this problem is a function y(t)y(t)y(t) that satisifies the differential equation on an interval III and whose graph includes the point (a,b)(a,b)(a,b). III is called the domain of the solution.

Verifying Solutions

To verify a solution to a differential equation, we can use substitution to prove that a function y(t)y(t)y(t) satisfies the differential equation y′(t)=F(t,y)y'(t)=F(t,y)y′(t)=F(t,y).

To prove y(t)=Ce2.5ty(t)=Ce^{2.5t}y(t)=Ce2.5t is a solution to the equation y′(t)=2.5y(t)y'(t)=2.5y(t)y′(t)=2.5y(t) (where CCC is an arbitrary constant), we differentiate y(t)=Ce2.5ty(t)=Ce^{2.5t}y(t)=Ce2.5t to get y′(t)=2.5Ce2.5ty'(t)=2.5Ce^{2.5t}y′(t)=2.5Ce2.5t.

y′(t)=2.5Ce2.5t=2.5Ce2.5t=2.5y(t)y'(t)=2.5Ce^{2.5t}=2.5Ce^{2.5t}=2.5y(t)y′(t)=2.5Ce2.5t=2.5Ce2.5t=2.5y(t)

This means that the function y(t)y(t)y(t) satisfies the equation y′(t)y'(t)y′(t) for any value of CCC. From this, we know that y(t)y(t)y(t) is a family of solutions of the differential equation.
